title: JavaScript is weird.
description: Get exposed to all of JavaScripts weirdness.

questions.explanation: When using the + operator with arrays, JavaScript first coerces both arrays to strings by joining their elements with commas. After coercion the expression becomes '1,2' + '1,2' == '1,21,2'. This expression evaluates to true.

When you use the + operator with an array [] and a number, JavaScript coerces the array into an empty string ''. After type coercion the expression becomes '' + 1 == '1'. This expression evaluates to true.

questions.question: true - true == false
questions.explanation: When using arithmetic operators with booleans, JavaScript coerces the booleans to numbers. true coerces to 1 and false coerces to 0. After coercion, the expression becomes 1 - 1 == 0. This expression evaluates to true.

questions.question: ({} == '[object Object]')
questions.explanation: When comparing an object {} to a string, the object will be coerced into a string. The string representation of an {} is '[object Object]'. After coercion the expression becomes '[object Object]' == '[object Object]'. This expression evaluates to true.

questions.question: undefined + 'a' === 'undefineda'
questions.explanation: When using arithmetic operators with undefined and a string, JavaScript coerces the undefined value into a string. The string representation of undefined is 'undefined'. After coercion the expression becomes 'undefined' + 'a' == 'undefineda'. This expression evaluates to true.

questions.question: NaN + [1,3] == 'NaN1,3'
questions.explanation: When using arithmetic operators with NaN and an array, JavaScript coerces NaN to the string 'NaN' and the array is coerced to the string '1,3'. After coercion, the expression becomes 'NaN' + '1,3' == 'NaN1,3'. This expression evaluates to true.
JavaScript compares numbers just as you would expect. Larger numbers are less than smaller numbers. This expression evaluates to false.
The number of trailing zeros does not matter. Both 1.0 and 1.00 represent the same numeric value. This comparison evaluates to true.
Even when compared strictly, the number of trailing zeros doesn't matter. Both 1.0 and 1.00 represent the same numeric value. This comparison evaluates to true.

Floating-point arithmetic in JavaScript can sometimes lead to unexpected results due to how floating-point numbers are represented internally. In this case, 0.1 + 0.2 results in 0.30000000000000004, not 0.3. This expression evaluates to false.
JavaScript mostly follows PEMDAS (Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication, Division, Addition, Subtraction). This expression evaluates to true.

questions.question: 'a' > 'b'
questions.explanation: String comparison is based on Unicode values. 'b' comes after 'a' in the Unicode table. This expression evaluates to false.

questions.question: 'dog' > 'cat'
questions.explanation: When comparing strings, JavaScript compares Unicode values letter by letter. Letters later in the alphabet are considered greater than letters earlier in the alphabet. In this case, 'd' is greater than 'c'. This comparison evaluates to true.

questions.question: 'cats' > 'cat'
questions.explanation: If all else is equal, the longest string is considered the greatest. This expression evaluates to true.

questions.question: 'zz' > 'aaaa'
questions.explanation: JavaScript will first compare letter by letter which takes precedence over the length of the string. Therefore, we are comparing 'z' and 'a'. This expression evaluates to true.
To know the answer to this question, you must also know the unicode values of these characters. This comparison evaluates to false.

questions.question: 'a' - 'a' == ''
questions.explanation: When performing subtraction on two strings, each string is coerced to a number. 'a' as a number is NaN. After coercion the expression is NaN - NaN == ''. This comparison evaluates to false.

questions.question: 'a' * 'a' == 'aa'
questions.explanation: When performing multiplication on two strings, the result is NaN. This comparison evaluates to false.

questions.question: 'a' * 2 == 'aa'
questions.explanation: When performing multiplication on a string and a number, the result is NaN. This comparison evaluates to false.

title: Numbers vs. Strings
description: Learn how numbers compare to strings.

questions.explanation: When comparing strings to numbers, JavaScript coerces strings into numbers. The string '1' is coerced to the number 1. After coercion, the expression becomes 1 == 1. This comparison evaluates to true.

questions.question: 'a' > 0
questions.explanation: When comparing a string and a number, JavaScript coerces strings to numbers. The string 'a' gets coerced to NaN. After coercion, the expression becomes NaN > 0. This comparison evaluates to false.

When using the + operator with a number and a string, JavaScript performs string concatenation. In this case, '10' is concatenated to 10, resulting in '1010'. The strict equality operator checks both value and type. '1010' is not strictly equal to 1010. This expression evaluates to false.

When dividing a number by a string, JavaScript performs type coercion. The string '10' is converted to a number, resulting in 100 / 10 which is 10. The strict comparison checks both value and type, and in this case, 10 (a number) is strictly equal to 10. This expression evaluates to true.
The first numerical 10's will be added normally. The comparison then becomes 20 + '10' == 30. String concatenation then occurs, and the result is '2010' == 30. This expression evaluates to false.
Now, because the second item is a string, JavaScript will resort to string concatenation. The resulting expression is '101010' == 30. This expression evaluates to false.

questions.question: true > false
questions.explanation: When comparing booleans, JavaScript converts both booleans to numbers. true coerced to a number is 1. false coerced to a number is 0. The comparison after type coercion is 1 > 0. This comparison evaluates to true.

questions.question: true === true
questions.explanation: In JavaScript, true is considered loosely and strictly equal to true.

questions.question: false === false
questions.explanation: In JavaScript, false is considered loosely and strictly equal to false.

questions.question: true - true == false
questions.explanation: When performing mathematical operations on booleans, booleans will be coerced to numbers. true coerced to a number is 1. false coerced to a number is 0. The comparison after coercion is 1 - 1 == 0. This comparison evaluates to true.

questions.question: true * true == true
questions.explanation: When performing mathematical operations on booleans, booleans will be coerced to numbers. true coerced to a number is 1. The comparison after coercion is 1 * 1 == 1. This comparison evaluates to true.

questions.question: true + 'a' == 'truea'
questions.explanation: When adding a boolean to a string, JavaScript will coerce the boolean to a string and perform string concatenation. The resulting expression is 'true' + 'a' == 'truea'. This comparison evaluates to true.

questions.question: true + 1 == 2
questions.explanation: When adding a boolean to a number, JavaScript will coerce the boolean to a number and perform addition. The resulting expression is 1 + 1 == 2. This comparison evaluates to true.

title: Booleans vs. Numbers
description: Learn how booleans compare to numbers.

questions.question: true == 1
questions.explanation: When comparing a boolean to a number, the boolean will be coerced to a number. true coerced to a number is 1. After coercion the comparison becomes 1 == 1. This comparison evaluates to true.

questions.question: true + 10 === 11
questions.explanation: In JavaScript, when a boolean value (true) is used with the + operator, it's converted to a number (1). Thus, the expression becomes 1 + 10 === 11. This expression evaluates to true.

questions.question: false + 10 === 9
questions.explanation: In JavaScript, `false` is coerced to the number 0 when used with the `+` operator. The comparison after coercion is 0 + 10 === 9. This expression evaluates to false.

questions.question: false == 0
questions.explanation: false is loosely equal to 0. This expression evaluates to true

questions.question: false === 0
questions.explanation: When using strict equality false is not equal to 0, although when using loose equality, it is. This comparison evaluates to false.

title: Booleans vs Strings
description: Learn how booleans compare to strings.

questions.question: true == 'a'
questions.explanation: When comparing a boolean to a string, both will be coerced to a number. true coerced to a number is 1. 'a' coerced to a number is NaN. After coercion the comparison becomes 1 == NaN. This comparison evaluates to false.

questions.question: true === 'true'
questions.explanation: When comparing a boolean to a string, JavaScript coerces both into numbers. true coerced to a number is 1. The string 'true' coerced to a number is NaN. After coercion the comparison is 1 == NaN. This comparison evaluates to false.

questions.question: true > 'a'
questions.explanation: When comparing a boolean to a string, both will be coerced to a number. true coerced to a number is 1. 'a' coerced to a number is NaN. After coercion the comparison becomes 1 > NaN. This comparison evaluates to false.

title: Null and Undefined
description: Learn how null and undefined behave.

questions.question: null === null
questions.explanation: null is loosely and strictly equal to null.

questions.question: undefined === undefined
questions.explanation: undefined is loosely and strictly equal to undefined.

questions.question: null == undefined
questions.explanation: In JavaScript, null and undefined are loosely equal. This expression evaluates to true.

questions.question: null === undefined
questions.explanation: In JavaScript, null is loosely equal to undefined but not stricly. This expresion evaluates to false.

title: Null and Undefined vs Numbers
description: Learn how null and undefined compare to numbers.

questions.question: null == 0
questions.explanation: null is only stricly equal to null and loosely equal to undefined. null is not equal to zero. This expression evaluates to false.

questions.question: Number(null) === 0
questions.explanation: The number representation of null is 0. This expression is true.

questions.question: null + 1 === 1
questions.explanation: When performaing mathmatical operations on null with a number, the null will coerced into a number. null as a number is 0. The expression becomes 0 + 1 == 1. This expression evaluates to true.

questions.question: null - 1 === -1
questions.explanation: Again, when performaing mathmatical operations on null with a number, the null will be coerced into a number. null as a number is 0. The expression becomes 0 - 1 == -1. This expression evaluates to true.

questions.question: Number(undefined) == 0
questions.explanation: The numerical representation of undefined is NaN. This expression evaluates to false.

questions.question: undefined + 1 == 1
questions.explanation: The numerical representation of undefined is NaN. After type coercion this expression becomes NaN + 1 === 0. This expression evaluates to false.

title: Null and Undefined vs. Strings
description: Learn how null and undefined compare to strings.

questions.question: null + 'a' === 'nulla'
questions.explanation: When performaing mathmatical operations on null with a string, null will coerced into a string. null as a string is 'null'. The expression becomes 'null' + 'a' === 'nulla'. This expression evaluates to true.

questions.question: String(null) == 'null'
questions.explanation: Again, The string respresentation of null is 'null'. This expression evaluates to true.

questions.question: undefined + 'a' === 'undefineda'
questions.explanation: When performaing mathmatical operations on undefined with a string, undefined will coerced into a string. undefined as a string is 'undefined'. The expression becomes 'undefined' + 'a' == 'undefineda'. This expression evaluates to true.

questions.question: undefined - 'a' == undefined
questions.explanation: When performing subtraction, undefined will be coerced to the string 'undefined'. 'undefined' - 'a' == NaN. NaN is not equal to undefined. This expression evaluates to false.
Yeah, JavaScript does this. It turns both arrays into strings and concatenates them. This expression evaluates to true.
When comparing an array to a string, the array will be coerced into a string. The string respresentation of an [] is ''. This expression evaluates to true.

questions.question: [].toString() == ''
questions.explanation: Again, The string respresentation of an [] is an empty string. This expression evaluates to true.
When comparing an array to a number, the array will be coerced into a number. An array as a number is 0. This expression evaluates to true.

questions.question: Number([]) == 0
questions.explanation: Again, The numerical respresentation of an [] is 0. This expression evaluates to true.

questions.question: ({} == '[object Object]')
questions.explanation: When comparing an object to a string, the object will be coerced into a string. The string respresentation of an object is '[object Object]'. This expression evaluates to true.

questions.question: ({}.toString() == '[object Object]')
questions.explanation: In JavaScript, when an object is converted to a string, its default string representation is '[object Object]'. So, `({}).toString() == '[object Object]'` evaluates to true.
JavaScript will coerce the {} into a number. The numerical respresentation of an {} is NaN. This expression evaluates to false

questions.question: Number({}) == 0
questions.explanation: The numerical respresentation of an {} is NaN. The comparison becomes NaN == 0. This expression evaluates to false.
The expression '{}' + [] results in the string '[object Object]' concatenated with an empty array, which becomes the string '[object Object]'. When compared with the number 0, it evaluates to false.

title: Objects and Arrays vs Numbers
description: Learn how objects and arrays compare to numbers.

questions.explanation: An object and an array are different types and have different memory references. This expression evaluates to false.
Two different objects have different memory references. This expression evaluates to false.

questions.question: [] + {} == '[object Object]'
questions.explanation: When preforming mathmatical operations on arrays and objects and comparing them to strings, they will be coerced to strings. [] coerced to a string is ''. {} coerced to a string is '[object Object]'. The comparison after coercion is  '' + '[object Object]' == '[object Object]'. This comparison evalutes to true.

When performaing mathmatical operations on a array with a number, the array will coerced into a string. [] as a string is an empty string. The expression becomes '' + 1 == 1. Because == means loose equality, this expression evaluates to true.

title: Objects and Arrays vs Strings
description: Learn how objects and arrays compare to strings

questions.explanation: An object and an array are different types and have different memory references. This expression evaluates to false.
Two different objects have different memory references. This expression evaluates to false.

questions.question: [] + {} == '[object Object]'
questions.explanation: When preforming mathmatical operations on arrays and objects and comparing them to strings, they will be coerced to strings. [] coerced to a string is an empty string. {} coerced to a string is '[object Object]'. The comparison after coercion is  '' + '[object Object]' == '[object Object]'. This comparison evalutes to true.
When performaing mathmatical operations on a array with a number, the array will coerced into a number. [] as a number is 0. The expression becomes 0 + 1 == 1. This expression evaluates to true.

questions.question: Infinity == Infinity
questions.explanation: Infinity is strictly equal to Infinity.

questions.question: -Infinity == -Infinity
questions.explanation: -Infinity is strictly equal to -Infinity.

questions.question: Infinity * 2 === Infinity
questions.explanation: Mathmatically, Infinity multiplied by anything is Infinity. This expression evaluates to true.

questions.question: Infinity * -1 === -Infinity
questions.explanation: Multiplying Infinity by a negative number will change it's sign. This expression evaluates to true.

questions.question: Infinity + 'andbeyond' == 'Infinityandbeyond'
questions.explanation: When performaing mathmatical operations on Infinity with a string, Infinity will coerced into a string. Infinity as a string is 'Infinity'. String concatention will then occur. This expression evaluates to true.

questions.question: Infinity - Infinity == 0
questions.explanation: Infinity - Infinity equals NaN. This expression evaluates to false.

questions.question: NaN == NaN
questions.explanation: NaN is equal to nothing, including itself. This expression evaluates to false.

questions.question: NaN + 1 == 1
questions.explanation: When adding NaN to a number, JavaScript will coerce NaN to a number and perform addition. NaN as a number is NaN. This comparison evaluates to false.

questions.question: NaN + 'a' == 'NaNa'
questions.explanation: When adding NaN to a string, JavaScript will coerce NaN to a string and perform string concatenation. The resulting expression is 'NaN' + 'a' == 'NaNa'. This comparison evaluates to true.

questions.question: NaN + [1,3] == 'NaN1,3'
questions.explanation: Yep, JavaScript does this lol.
